message: Some thoughts on tonight's #JointAddress:  I was excited to hear the President discuss school choice and ensuring every American child has access to a quality education. This is truly the key to our nation's future, and I will continue working with my colleagues and the White House to make these improvements a reality.  I was pleased to hear President Trump address many issues critical to everyday Americans, such as job creation, tax reform, national security, supporting our military and veterans, and improving addiction treatment services. We heard many ideas from the President tonight where I believe we can find common ground and produce real solutions for the American people, and I look forward to continuing my work with colleagues in Congress to do so.  The President made a strong call for the principles that will guide the replacement of Obamacare. I look forward to passing legislation that repeals Obamacare and builds a sustainable system for all American families.  The President is correct that we must tackle the violence that is harming many of our communities. I believe this means bringing our law enforcement and communities together to better understand and find solutions for the issues they both face. I will continue my work with Trey Gowdy and others in this vital area.  We saw the true power of the American spirit tonight with the recognition of Carryn Owens, the widow of US Navy SEAL Chief William Ryan Owens. It was one of the most powerful moments I have ever witnessed, and our never-ending gratitude remains with Ryan and all of those who have sacrificed for our nation. God Bless them, and God Bless the United States of America.

I just voted for Rep. Ryan Zinke to serve as Secretary of the Interior. The Senate approved Zinke's appointment by a vote of 68-31.  Having grown up on the coast, I appreciate the important balance of both protecting our natural resources and utilizing our federal lands and waters for recreation, economic development, and energy production. The Secretary of the Interior plays a critical role in ensuring our public lands and waters are available for multiple use purposes, and I am proud to support the confirmation of Congressman Zinke as Secretary today.

This morning, I voted for Dr. Ben Carson to be the next Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. The Senate approved Dr. Carsonâ€™s appointment by a vote of 58-41.  As Chairman of the subcommittee on Housing, Transportation, and Community Development, I have seen firsthand how the shortfalls of the prior HUD leadership have led to the appalling conditions that are an unfortunate reality for so many of our families who rely on our nationâ€™s federally funded public housing properties. We need someone to take over who will help bring a fresh perspective to a government agency in desperate need of innovative change, and that is why I voted to support Dr. Ben Carsonâ€™s nomination as our new HUD Secretary.

I just voted to confirm former Texas Governor Rick Perry to serve as Secretary of the Department of Energy. He was confirmed 62-37.  As Governor of Texas, Rick Perry oversaw an energy boom that helped create millions of new jobs in the state of Texas. His proven leadership is a great fit for the Department of Energy, which is critical to South Carolinaâ€™s nuclear waste cleanup efforts, and plays a major role in both energy development and our national security.  I look forward to working with Governor Perry to continue the MOX project at the Savannah River Site, building on the growth and innovation we have seen at the Savannah River National Lab, and holding the federal government accountable for the continued cleanup of the SRSâ€™s nuclear waste.

I believe all Americans should have the opportunity to succeed, and there is a strong necessity to create a pipeline of opportunity so that we can help our countryâ€™s most vulnerable citizens achieve the American Dream. That is why I am incredibly passionate about my Opportunity Agenda. It focuses on restoring hope in the lives of millions of Americans seeking a quality education, better opportunities, and those who simply wish to build a bridge to a brighter future for their families.   As part of my Opportunity Agenda, my CHOICE Act will help unlock the potential of students who might otherwise be left behind. Every single child in this country deserves access to a quality education, and the CHOICE Act was created to provide military families, parents of students with disabilities, and low-income families with more options so that their child can succeed.   My LEAP Act, also an important piece to my Opportunity Agenda, encourages folks to earn while they learn through apprenticeships.  In South Carolina, we have seen amazing results from apprenticeship programs, and the LEAP Act builds on the model we use in the state; it seeks to bring that success to the entire nation.   The final piece of my Opportunity Agenda is the bipartisan Investing in Opportunity Act, which would incentivize investment in economically distressed communities in every state, without creating a new government program. There are more than 50 million Americans living in poverty, and the IIOA would reinvest private sector dollars back into communities that need it the most.   As someone who grew up living paycheck to paycheck, I am committed to finding solutions to lifting up millions of families across the nation by creating a system that leads to a quality education and good paying jobs. And I think my Opportunity Agenda would certainly help brighten the path forward.
â€ªHonored to receive the South Carolina State University Foundation's Trailblazer Award tonight. SCSU and all HBCUs will continue to be a vital part of our future!â€¬

It is time we reimagine how we help lift people out of poverty. The American dream is alive and I want to help make it a reality for as many folks as possible. Today, 50 million Americans live in distressed regions that lack jobs and businesses. My Investing in Opportunity Act hopes to revitalize these areas by enticing private investments through a deferred capital gains tax. According to recent studies, U.S. investors have $2.3 trillion in unrealized capital gains. By creating a way for these funds to be invested in our most fragile communities, we will help generate job growth, prosperity, and opportunity to those who have lost hope.

March is Reading Awareness Month. Literacy is critical to an individualâ€™s success.   In U.S. prisons, between 60-80% of women and men are functionally illiterate. Thatâ€™s a staggering number. It shows how critical literacy can be for so many who may not believe the American Dream is accessible to them.    Join me in promoting the importance of literacy for Reading Awareness Month!
#InternationalWomensDay

When I think about ways we can tackle the issue of poverty and increase the likelihood of success, apprenticeships and job training come to mind. In South Carolina, we have witnessed a huge manufacturing renaissance through technical training. Folks are given the opportunity to acquire new skills, and in the case of apprenticeships, they can also earn while they learn.   That is why my LEAP Act is an important part of my Opportunity Agenda. It is modeled on our very successful program in South Carolina to incentivize employers to use apprenticeships. I am excited about the LEAP Act and our efforts to bring successful apprenticeship programs to communities across the nation.

Most of you are familiar with my story and know that as a kid mired in poverty, my education essentially saved my life. Iâ€™ve seen the power of education firsthand, and as a result, Iâ€™ve been a vocal champion for school choice and the necessity of a quality education.   Education is truly the key to the American Dream, and I continue to believe that when parents have more choices, their children have a better chance at succeeding. My CHOICE was built on this notion.   Too many students are not getting access to the education they deserve. That is why it is critical for us to ensure that families in every community have a variety of educational options at their disposal so that their kids can unleash their full potential. My CHOICE Act seeks to let parents of children with special needs, military families, and low-income households in our nationâ€™s capital decide whatâ€™s best for their individual childâ€™s needs. I am committed to improving our education system and will continue to fight for quality education for all students across our country!

So many Americans are searching for better opportunities to help lead them on the path to a brighter future. Whether it is through apprenticeships, quality education, or reinvesting in distressed communities, we must find ways to lift up those who feel like they have been left behind, like no one cares. I was one of those kids who lived paycheck-to-paycheck, almost flunked out of school, and completely unsure of what my future looked like. That is why my goal is to find solutions for many low-income families struggling across the country, and I believe my Opportunity Agenda is certainly a step towards ensuring all Americans have what they need to succeed.
Congrats to Winthrop Athletics and South Carolina Gamecocks on making the #NCAATournament!

This evening, I voted to confirm Seema Verma to be administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services. She was confirmed by the Senate 55-43.   I believe Ms. Seema Vermaâ€™s extensive career has given her a unique understanding into the intricacies of our healthcare systems. She has spearheaded Medicaid reform across six different states, was the key architect in drafting â€˜Healthy Indiana Planâ€™ for then-Governor Pence, and has consistently shown she understands the benefit of free-market alternatives when it comes to managing our healthcare programs. I am proud to support Ms. Verma during her nomination, and I believe she will advocate for better care and will do so efficiently and responsibly.

Today I questioned a FEMA official on the reauthorization of the National Flood Insurance Program in Senate Banking Committee. In South Carolina, we are in desperate need of remapping. In some communities, such as Beaufort County, we havenâ€™t seen remapping in about 20 years. I asked Mr. Wright about the technology behind this in regards to flood insurance, as well as the socioeconomic impact.

I questioned US Trade Representative nominee Robert Lighthizer in Senate Finance Committee this afternoon. Exporting is a huge part of our state's economy, and we talked about solutions to help South Carolinian and American producers and workers.

This afternoon, I voted to confirm my former colleague Senator Dan Coats to be Director of National Intelligence. His nomination was approved by the Senate 86-10.   Intelligence is the first line of defense in preventing attacks on our soil, and a critical countermeasure to helping prevent dangerous individuals from causing harm. The Director of National Intelligence has a monumental task of overseeing our intelligence entities and ensuring they are structured in a way that makes us more proactive in combatting terrorism. Senator Dan Coats, an Army veteran, former U.S. Ambassador, and former member of the Senate Intelligence Committee, is exceptionally qualified to serve as our next Director of National Intelligence, and I look forward to working with him in this new role.

Today, I introduced bipartisan legislation that would help lower energy prices. Congressman Tom Rice introduced a companion bill in the House. This is a more responsible and efficient way to deliver the incentives Congress created to construct new, clean nuclear power through public-private partnerships. South Carolina is leading the nation as a first mover in building advanced nuclear power facilities that help our energy sector to meet the needs and challenges of our stateâ€™s 21st century manufacturing economy. Most importantly, it will be a positive change that will benefit millions of South Carolina residents.  More information on my website: https://www.scott.senate.gov/press-release/senator-scott-congressman-rice-introduce-bipartisan-legislation-lower-energy-prices

I am proud to announce the nominations of 45 South Carolina students to the U.S. Military Service Academies for the class of 2021.   It is such an honor and privilege to nominate some of our stateâ€™s future leaders to our countryâ€™s military service academiesFor me, this is one of the best parts of my job. Each year, I look forward to taking the opportunity to review hundreds of applications from young people who have the passion and willingness to serve our country. My office received applications from so many impressive students from every part of the state, and I am confident they will go to their respective service academies and represent our state and country well.  View the full list here: https://www.scott.senate.gov/press-release/senator-scott-nominates-45-south-carolina-students-us-military-service-academies
Garnet and black. í ½í´¥ What a weekend for the men and women! #NCAAtournament

Judge Neil Gorsuch is a great pick to be a Supreme Court justice. Heâ€™s fair and impartial with an impressive record.   Looking forward to following his confirmation hearings in the Senate Judiciary Committee this week -
Wearing my #worlddownsyndromeday socks today in honor of my friend Rachel Lewis and all of the amazing people with Down Syndrome!
Happy #SingleParentDay! So fortunate to have been raised by a single mom who invested so much to help my brother & me reach our full potential.

This morning, I questioned Secretary of Labor nominee Alex Acosta in Senate HELP Committee. I asked him  how he would integrate apprenticeship programs, modeled after our successful program in South Carolina and my LEAP Act, into his agenda as Labor Secretary and about his approach to the overtime rule.
Had a great telephone town hall with Trey Gowdy and the people of the 4th District tonight. We talked health care, Russia, intelligence, the importance of a free press, school choice and more!
A little chilly outside today, but had a great time speaking with SC students from Socastee High School and Newberry Elementary at the Capitol
Excited about the menâ€™s Sweet 16 game against Baylor tonight! GO GAMECOCKS!! #NCAAtournament
Good luck USC womenâ€™s basketball today! #MarchMadness #GoGamecocks!
Joining Dana Bash on CNN State of the Union this morning with Senator James Lankford to discuss our #SolutionSunday initiative. Make sure to tune in!
Final.Four. Wow.

Solution Sunday is our initiative that encourages people who look different or come from different backgrounds to get together for simply a conversation over a meal. The goal is to help folks break down walls so that we can understand each other better and move towards uniting our country. Senator James Lankford and I joined CNN to discuss why our Solution Sunday initiative is so important and necessary.
Congrats to the men's team on making it to #finalfour! Cheering for the women tonight! #GoGamecocks #MarchMadness

Judge Gorsuch is a balanced jurist who understands the importance of an independent judiciary, and I respect him greatly. Read my column on his nomination here - https://greenvillejournal.com/2017/03/27/tim-scott-gorsuch-right-man-serve-supreme-court-justice/
In honor of National Vietnam Veterans Day, we recognize the brave service members who sacrificed for our freedom. Thank you.

I've seen quite a few posts regarding a recent vote on internet regulations. There has been quite a bit of misinformation spread about what this vote meant, and I hope I can ease your concerns.   First, and most importantly, my vote did not change a single thing regarding current privacy protections for your online data. The rule that was negated never even went into effect. Additionally, financial and health data are already protected regardless of where they exist by the Gramm Leach Biley Act and HIPAA, respectively.   The internet, from ISPs to companies like Google, has historically been regulated by the Federal Trade Commission (FTC). However, the Obama Administrationâ€™s Federal Communications Commission attempted to go around the law, established by Congress, by creating a new rule that would steal this regulatory ability for themselves. This would cause duplication, waste, and increased spending, with no evidence that the FTC was unable to continue doing the job they have done for the past decade. I simply voted to stop this rule from going into effect.   I take the privacy concerns of all Americans very seriously, and would not vote for legislation that I believe would allow for personal, private data to be released without permission. Thank you again for sharing your concerns.

With my Investing in Opportunity Act, I believe we have a real opportunity to move forward. Millions of hard-working families across the country are simply looking for the opportunity to succeed, and my bill, which already has significant bipartisan support, would help bring success back to all of America. It gives us a chance to positively impact distressed communities by incentivizing investment in these neighborhoods â€“ without creating a new government program. You will hear me speak about the Investing in Opportunity Act often because I am passionate about this piece of legislation, and excited about the hope it could restore in so many low-income families.
Congrats South Carolina Women's Basketball! National Champs!!!

Judge Neil Gorsuch is well-qualified and the right man to fill the ninth seat of our nationâ€™s highest court. Read why I support his nomination to the Supreme Court in Bluffton Today:  http://www.blufftontoday.com/opinion/2017-04-01/gorsuch-right-pick-supreme-court

Financial literacy has taught me that, despite where I started, I could achieve prosperity, and I believe it has the power to do the same for others. By laying the groundwork for financial literacy, we can help empower our youth and ensure they have the opportunity to reach their educational and financial goals.   April is Financial Literacy Month, and it is incredibly important for us to help our youth across the country develop best practices to improve their money management skills and achieve their dreams.

I want to thank the staff members and employees of Goodwill Industries International for allowing me to participate in todayâ€™s event as your advocacy luncheon guest speaker. While you were gracious enough to present me with a policymakerâ€™s award, you are all the ones that deserve all of the recognition. Every day you and your employees work tirelessly to help those in need. Through your efforts, you are not only changing lives, but you are changing the course for entire generations of Americans.

I spoke on the Senate floor in support of Judge Neil Gorsuch to become Supreme Court Justice today. Judge Gorsuch is a man who has led an exemplary life and deserves a fair vote. It is time for us to move past political games and confirm one of the brightest judicial minds our country has to offer.

Today I voted in favor of instituting the so called â€˜nuclear optionâ€™ in order to confirm Judge Neil Gorsuch to take over the ninth seat on the Supreme Court. It was not a decision I made lightly. It requires us to change the long-standing precedence of the Senate rules. However, it was also clear to me that this decision was a necessity. For the first time in the history of the Senate, Democrats have decided to conduct a partisan filibuster of a Supreme Court nominee. Todayâ€™s action is an example of what I call the physics of politicsâ€¦. For every reaction, there is an equal and opposite reaction. Judge Neil Gorsuch is an outstanding nominee and one of the brightest judicial minds our country has to offer. If my friends on the left are not willing to look past party lines to confirm this nominee, I doubt any nominee presented by a Republican president will ever get their vote.

Senator Roger Wicker settled our friendly wager with cheese & ice cream from Mississippi State University. Iâ€™ll be congratulating the University of South Carolina Lady Gamecocks on their big win from the Senate floor at 6pm! Tune in!
Congratulations to University of South Carolina Women's Basketball! Amazing season for South Carolina Gamecocks!

The U.S. response to the atrocities of this week should be a surprise to no one. The gut-wrenching photos of children gasping for breath and the families grieving over loved ones warranted a military response of equal proportions. This week it was confirmed a chemical attack carried out by the Assad regime brutally killed nearly 100 people, 27 of them children. Unfortunately, this is not the first time this has been done. Despite a standing agreement banning the use of chemical weapons, Assad has violated the guidelines time and time again. This was the last time it would go without consequences. This is not a knee-jerk reaction and there were plenty of warnings before arriving to this point. Thank you to the brave men and women in uniform for carrying out this justified and calculated attack on a military target. Our actions from last night should send a clear message that barbaric attacks against humanity will not be tolerated. We must continue to develop a comprehensive strategy moving forward.

Today, my colleagues and I voted to fill the most important position we are tasked to fill, and I walk away confident that we have made a great decision for America by confirming an exemplary man, Judge Neil Gorsuch. He has proven through his phenomenal record that he is dedicated to the rule of law and the right man for the job. I believe Neil Gorsuch will be an excellent addition to our nationâ€™s highest court, and I am excited to witness his contributions as an associate justice.
Happy #NationalSiblingsDay to my two amazing brothers, Ben and Earl, who have both served our nation in our Armed Forces!

April is the Month of the Military Child. There are nearly 200,000 children living on domestic military installations, and according to the Department of Defense, kids in military families will move 6 to 9 times throughout their educational career  - three times more than nonmilitary families. It is important for our men and women in our nationâ€™s Armed Forces to know their children are receiving the best possible education. That is why a third of my CHOICE Act focuses on these military families. As someone who lived on an Air Force base as a kid, I can relate to being faced with limited school options while living on a military base. The CHOICE Act would create a DoD pilot on at least 5 bases without DoD Education Activity schools to ensure military parents have choices.  Our service members sacrifice so much on behalf of our amazing country and deserve to know their children are receiving the best education available.

Happy National Internship Awareness Month! Internships are a vital part of our workforce and are mutually beneficial to both employers and interns. Employers are given the chance to get to know potential new employees, while students are able gain experience in the fields they are interested in and make connections that may be advantageous to them in the future.   Through my internship program, I have met many hard working and dedicated young professionals who have bright futures ahead of them. Their contributions to my office have been invaluable. Thank you to all interns for your continued hard work!

With approximately 50 million people living in distressed communities (1.4 million in South Carolina), we need new, innovative ideas to fight poverty and bring opportunity to families across the nation. My Opportunity Agenda, which has been my primary focus here in the Senate, focuses on creating more opportunities for our countryâ€™s most vulnerable citizens. Whether it is through apprenticeships, quality education, or reinvesting in low-income families, the Opportunity Agenda is a great step towards positively impacting families living paycheck-to-paycheck, seeking a better path to a brighter future.   In addition, the Senate Opportunity Coalition, a group of conservative senators, is committed to bringing the issue of poverty to the forefront. We have met with folks in our respective states, heard their stories, listened to their concerns, and now we are excited to begin working on the right solutions. I look forward to continue working with the coalition to help bring long-lasting change and hope back in the communities that need it the most.
Wishing you and your family a blessed #GoodFriday, and an amazing #Easter weekend
He is risen. Happy Easter from my family to yours!

30% of our state's population lives in distressed zip codes. The Investing in Opportunity Act seeks to help many folks living paycheck-to-paycheck, and will reinvest private sector dollars back into helping everyday Americans improve their quality of life.  Our most vulnerable communities across the country lack opportunities, investment potential, and tangible growth. Businesses are closing and we are facing a shortage of entrepreneurs.  We want to revolutionize how we help some of our most financially distressed neighborhoods.   https://www.scott.senate.gov/press-release/senator-scott-introduces-bipartisan-investing-opportunity-act

I introduced the Restraining Excessive Seizure of Property through Exploitation of Civil Asset Forfeiture Tools (RESPECT) Act. Government entities should not be allowed to seize Americans' property without first meeting a set burden of proof. A Congressional investigation found that the IRS has taken advantage of their civil forfeiture authority, and seized property without justification. The residual effects hurt our small business owners, and by extension their employees. It is time we work toward restoring basic constitutional rights to our citizens.  https://www.scott.senate.gov/press-release/senators-scott-brown-lead-effort-stop-irs%E2%80%99s-abuse-its-civil-forfeiture-authority
Enjoyed our conversation on race and the economy at Winthrop University  last night w/ Trey Gowdy

I believe education is the closest thing to magic. My CHOICE Act seeks to let parents of children with special needs, military families, and low-income households decide whatâ€™s best for their individual childâ€™s needs. I have personally experienced the power of education in my life, and I am confident if our most vulnerable children see the light, they will move in that direction â€” and that is good news for kids who grew up like me.
Had a great time visiting the 12th grade American Government class at Ashley Ridge High School this morning

I voted to confirm former Georgia governor, Sonny Perdue, to serve as our next Secretary of Agriculture. He was confirmed 87-11.  Our stateâ€™s thriving agriculture industry has expanded significantly within the last decade and today South Carolina is home to about 25,000 farms spanning across 4.9 million acres.  Even more importantly, the industry provides 212,000 jobs to hardworking residents and has reached an annual economic impact of more than $41 billion. Today, I was pleased to vote in support of former Georgia governor, Sonny Perdue, to serve as our next Secretary because I think he is the type of experienced leader that will work tirelessly to ensure this type of agricultural growth remains unhindered in our state, and similar success is reflected across the country. As someone who grew up on a farm and owned his own farming business, Mr. Perdue has firsthand experience in understanding the unique needs of our agriculture industry and recognizes the monumental role the agricultural industry plays in supporting our nationâ€™s economy.
Great time with some of our state's brightest future leaders from River Bluff High School (Lexington) who are in DC for their 'We the People' Competition!

I questioned John Lettieri of the Economic Innovation Group in Small Business Committee on addressing upward mobility in struggling communities, such as Saluda and Williamsburg counties in South Carolina. Iâ€™m excited about my bipartisan Investing in Opportunity Act because it allows temporary tax deferment of capital gains and dividends to incentivize investment into those communities that have fallen further behind. Watch below:
This morning I questioned witnesses in Senate Banking Committee on the effectiveness of our current sanctions against Russia. Watch below:

Tonight, the Senate confirmed Alex Acosta to serve as Labor Secretary (60-38).   Once Mr. Acosta officially assumes his new position, I hope his focus will be to unleash the power of the American workforce by promoting labor policies that are free of unnecessarily burdensome federal regulations. Specifically, I will be interested to see how he plans to permanently take the overtime and fiduciary rules off the table. Both are examples of the previous administrationâ€™s government overreach agenda, and moving forward our attention should be on protecting our hardworking employees, and not creating more extraneous layers of bureaucracy and wasted tax dollars.
As a kid who grew up mired in poverty,  I have seen the power of education in my life. I believe it is truly the closest thing to magic.

May is Military Appreciation Month. Thank you to all our brave service members â€“ past and present.  I want to especially acknowledge our South Carolina service members and veterans, and those who are currently stationed at one of our military bases. Whether it is our Marines stationed in Parris Island and Beaufort, our Airmen at Shaw, our soldiers at Fort Jackson, our sailors at Naval Weapons Station-Charleston, our coast guardsmen at USCG Sectorâ€¦ you all have made us so incredibly proud of everything you have, and continue to accomplish.

This week marks a new chapter for a family and a community who were left with more questions than answers after months of court proceedings culminated in a mistrial last December. While there is absolutely nothing that can be done to ease the pain of losing a loved one in such a senseless and infuriating manner, I was relieved to see that a guilty plea was officially filed in the case. Like it was said by Walter Scott's brother, for their family, 'the healing starts today.' The Scott family has been patiently waiting for this day. A day that would bring them justice and closure after months of feeling so much pain and anguish. They were relying on the judicial system and I'm thankful for the outcome thus far.

This morning in Senate Banking Committee, I questioned witnesses on the reauthorization of the National Flood Insurance Program. In 2015, the flood in South Carolina devastated so many families. And as I surveyed places like Sumter, I discovered that almost none of the families had flood insurance. This issue concerns me. I believe this also reinforces the necessity for nationwide mapping to be more accurate so that South Carolina, and other states are better prepared for recovery. Watch below:

I voted against the trillion-dollar omnibus spending bill today.   While the recent budget added billions of dollars to our military budget, border security enhancements, and funded important education resources, it fell short in many other areas. We still saw funding for programs that do not make efficient use of federal funds, like continued financial backing for Obamacare. I would have preferred to see a more significant shift in how we spend taxpayer money.
Congrats to the Class of 2017 at Allen University! Amazing time speaking at this morning's commencement! #DreamBig
I enjoyed meeting with seniors from Northside Christian School in between votes today. After speaking with them, I'm excited about their futures! Smart students.

Happy Teacher Appreciation Day and Week! Growing up, I was blessed to have teachers like Mrs. Lynch and Mrs. Greenburg who provided me with a strong academic foundation to stand on. To all the teachers across the nation, thank you for all you do and the difference you make every day!

I voted in support of Dr. Scott Gottlieb to serve as our next Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration.  As both a physician and cancer survivor, Dr. Gottlieb brings a unique experience-set that will help him approach situations both as a medical professional and a patient. Not only is he exceptionally qualified, but his nomination has received support from nearly 50 various medical organizations, and he has also been highly regarded by three former FDA commissioners. I hope he will help bring a common-sense approach to how the FDA is managed, especially in how we empower innovation to ensure every patient has access to the most groundbreaking treatments available.

Regardless of what they are saying today, Democrats have continually called for Director Comey to be fired over the past six months. Multiple federal entities are currently and independently conducting Russia investigations, including the Senate Intelligence Committee. Chairman Burr and Ranking Member Warner have repeatedly demonstrated they are working together to uncover all of the facts, and I have no reason to believe they wonâ€™t.   I also do not believe that the Directorâ€™s dismissal will affect how the FBI carries out its investigations, and I have full confidence in the brave men and women serving our nation every day at the FBI. I look forward to the Senate Intelligence Committeeâ€™s report, and to reviewing that and any findings made by the FBI at the conclusion of their investigations.

Another major insurer leaves Obamacare, meaning even more states are down to just one insurer on the exchange. In fact, more than half of states have at least one county with only a single insurer on the exchange. That's leaving families with fewer choices and even higher premiums.  It's well past time to find a solution that ensures all Americans have access to quality, affordable care.   http://money.cnn.com/2017/05/10/news/economy/aetna-obamacare/

Today, I voted in support of Robert Lighthizer to serve as our next U.S. Trade Representative.   Our trade policies should focus on supporting the American worker. They are the backbone of our country and deserve an administration that is willing to stand up and fight to keep jobs from being shipped abroad. The Port of Charleston, and the nearly 10 percent of South Carolina jobs it provides, relies heavily on a strong trade policy that makes our goods competitive in overseas markets.  I believe Mr. Lighthizer is the right choice to serve as our top trade representative, and I look forward to seeing how he tackles our out-of-control trade deficit and helps to refine our bilateral international agreements.

Today, let us honor our military spouses â€“ whether our service members are working long hours training for their next mission or spending months away from home to protect our freedom, our military spouses deserve the utmost admiration for the amazing job they do in holding down the home front. Our dedicated military spouses are working hard every day, often times filling the role of two parents, so that our brave men and women in uniform can focus on accomplishing their mission. You all are heroes, and I just want to say thank you for your dedication and commitment to our nation.

Growing up, my mom taught me that if you shoot for the moon, and you miss, youâ€™ll be among the stars. Happy Motherâ€™s Day to my mom, Frances Scott, and all the moms out there who sacrifice so much for their families!

They are the backbone of our country and deserve an administration that is willing to stand up and fight to keep jobs from being shipped abroad. The Port of Charleston, and the nearly 10 percent of South Carolina jobs it provides, relies heavily on a strong trade policy that makes our goods competitive in overseas markets.  I believe Mr. Lighthizer is the right choice to serve as our top trade representative, and I look forward to seeing how he tackles our out-of-control trade deficit and helps to refine our bilateral international agreements.

I believe Mr. Lighthizer is the right choice to serve as our top trade representative, and I look forward to seeing how he tackles our out-of-control trade deficit and helps to refine our bilateral international agreements.
Joined Dana Bash tonight for Politics on Tap (although I just had water)!
The foundation of Obamacare is broken.  http://www.postandcourier.com/news/five-health-insurance-companies-once-sold-obamacare-policies-in-south/article_15e4807c-3405-11e7-afce-77050428d317.html
Trey Gowdy and I met with 5th graders from Simpsonville Elementary and Taylors Elementary today at the Capitol! Fun times!

Today I announced that I will reintroduce the Safer Officers and Safer Citizens Act, which will help provide state, local and tribal police departments with needed resources to outfit officers with body-worn camera.   As the use of body cameras continues to rise across the nation, we see more and more just how important they can be in efforts to keep both police officers and the communities they serve safer. Our nation has experienced too much pain and heartache from tragedies that could have been more clearly explained if body cameras were in use. While there is no panacea, body cameras are without a doubt a positive step forward, and I will continue to advocate for this important legislation with my colleagues in Congress.  https://www.scott.senate.gov/press-release/sen-scott-reintroduce-body-camera-legislation

Great news about our state's apprenticeship programs, which have already reached the enrollment goals originally set for 2020. My LEAP Act, a major component of my Opportunity Agenda, is based on our state's great model, and I'm confident we will continue to see the benefits of apprenticeships well into the future!  http://www.postandcourier.com/business/south-carolina-s-apprenticeship-initiative-cracks-growth-milestone-as-new/article_72157c86-3c05-11e7-9514-7bb6c3409ac9.html

I believe that if a picture is worth a thousand words, then a video is worth a thousand pictures, and I am confident that the deployment of body-worn cameras will provide increased protection for law enforcement officers and the communities they serve. One study found that after implementing the use of body cameras, community complaints were reduced by 93%.   I look forward to reintroducing my Safer Officers and Safer Citizens Act to help keep both communities and offices safer. You can read more about what my body camera legislation here - https://www.scott.senate.gov/press-release/sen-scott-reintroduce-body-camera-legislation

Obamacare has turned out to be the Unaffordable Care Act, and thatâ€™s not fair to millions of families from South Carolina to Oregon. Thatâ€™s why my Republican colleagues and I in the Senate continue our work on a new health care bill that emphasizes lower costs for families and access to high quality care for all.

I reintroduced my bipartisan Safer Officers and Safer Citizens Act. This bill will help provide body-worn cameras to state, local, and tribal police departments. Today, the Senate unanimously passed the Department of Veterans Affairs Accountability and Whistleblower Protection Act -- a bipartisan bill that would improve accountability procedures at the VA.   Our veterans deserve the absolute best care possible. Unfortunately, subpar management, long wait lines, and lack of accountability have plagued the Department of Veterans Affairs for years. While many VA employees do an amazing job every day, the fact remains there are those who fall short, and we must ensure standards improve and excellent service becomes the new norm at our VA facilities. I remain committed to continuing to serve our veterans and service members whenever possible. As the White House prepares to make new announcements on workforce development this week, I am continuing my years long work in this area. My bipartisan LEAP Act incentivizes companies to expand their apprenticeship programs using a South Carolina-style model to help folks earn while they learn.  I am excited to see the White House put workforce development and the skills gap at the forefront. Whether it be the SKILLS Act passed a couple of years ago, my bipartisan LEAP Act that I introduced in this Congress, or encouraging career and technical education, there are some concrete steps we can take to ensure the needs of employers better match the skills of our workforce. This is an exciting week, and I look forward to working with the White House and my colleagues in Congress to make these solutions a reality.  Many employers explain the reason for their unfilled jobs as a lack of available trained workers. Apprenticeships are a proven way to help people develop in-demand skills and to meet the needs of employers, yet they compose just 0.2 percent of the nationâ€™s workforce. By 2020, the United States is expected to experience a shortage of 3 million workers with associate degrees or higher and 5 million workers with technical certificates and credentials.  In 2016 in the U.S. there were approximately 505,000 active apprentices in registered apprenticeship programs. By contrast, in Germany nearly 50 percent of all young people go through apprenticeship programs.  Studies show that apprenticeships are a wise investment for both participants and the U.S. government: individuals who complete registered apprenticeship programs earn over $240,000 more over their careers than people who did not participate in such programs, and the tax return on every Federal Government dollar invested in registered apprenticeship programs is $27.

Every American wants the opportunity to succeed, and it is important for us to support families striving to achieve the American Dream. These families are looking for a hand-up, not a handout, and I am proud to work alongside my colleagues Senators Blunt, Reed, and Menendez on this critical issue to help low-income families seeking better opportunities prosper.  https://www.scott.senate.gov/press-release/scott-blunt-reed-menendez-introduce-legislation-improve-education-economic

I just voted for strengthened sanctions on both Iran and Russia. Actions and provocations by both Iran and Russia continue to show their unwillingness to work with us on establishing peace and stability. They quite simply have left us no choice but to strengthen sanctions. I was glad to join such a strong contingent of my colleagues to send a clear message that these actions and programs will not be tolerated.  The Countering Iran's Destabilizing Activities Act accomplishes the following:  Russia - Included a bipartisan amendment I co-sponsored to expand existing economic sanctions against Russia and allow Congress to review any action by the President to lift existing penalties.  Iran -  Target Iranâ€™s Ballistic Missile Program: Imposes sanctions on persons engaged in efforts to manufacture, acquire, possess, develop, transport, transfer, or use ballistic missiles. Includes anyone that knowingly provides, or attempts to provide, financial, material, technological, or other support to the individuals above.  Target Iranâ€™s Terrorism and Conventional Arms Trade: Imposes terrorism-related sanctions on Iranâ€™s Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps (IRGC) Places sanctions on persons who kill or torture those who wish to exercise or defend internationally recognized human rights or wish to expose illegal activity in Iran.  Places sanctions on persons who violate the arms embargo placed on Iran.  Other Provisions include: Prohibits the lifting of sanctions on those mentioned above unless the person has ceased support for the relevant activity for three months Mandates the creation of a US strategy to counter Iranian conventional and asymmetric activities that threaten US and our allies in the Middle East. Requires a report on US citizens detained in Iran and those who hold them. Requires a report on discrepancies between US and European sanctions targeting Iran. Provides authority to waive sanctions against persons on case-by-case basis for a period of no more than 180 days, if such a waiver is vital to US security interests.

It's hard to believe it has been ten years since the Charleston Sofa Super Store fire. That day we lost nine brave, selfless firefighters forever. With more than 100 years of service between them, these nine men put their lives on the line for all of us many times, and we will never forget their ultimate sacrifice. The families and friends of the Charleston 9 remain in our prayers, and their memories will live on eternally.

The Reverend Clementa Pinckney Cynthia Hurd The Reverend Sharonda Coleman-Singleton Tywanza Sanders Ethel Lance Susie Jackson Depayne Middleton Doctor The Reverend Daniel Simmons Myra Thompson  Two years ago, on June 17th 2015, we experienced one of the greatest atrocities South Carolina has ever known. Our city and our state were left shaken and heartbroken. The horrific actions of a man filled with hate took the lives of nine parishioners.  However, in the face of evil, nine families and the congregation at Mother Emanuel taught us the power of love and forgiveness. We must honor the memory of the Emanuel 9 by working to come together, and ensure that hate does not win. Their families showed us how much better we are united, and we all need to take that to heart.

I discussed ideas at Banking Committee this morning to make the housing market work better for American workers and their families. More Americans than ever work in the â€œgig economyâ€ and donâ€™t know exactly what their income will be month-to-month, but their mortgage or rent payments stay the same.

This week, I introduced two important pieces of legislation for our state. I teamed up with Senator Brian Schatz for the Repeatedly Flooded Communities Preparation Act, which will ensure better protection for communities that have been repeatedly flooded. This bill would help communities like Sumter, Horry County and other areas around South Carolina after the 2015 floods better prepare for weather disasters before they strike.   I also introduced the Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie National Park Act with Congressman Mark Sanford, which will provide oversight and protection to some of South Carolinaâ€™s most significant sites. The bill, which has already received support from the Charleston Metro Chamber of Commerce and the Fort Sumter-Fort Moultrie Historical Trust, establishes a clear management plan for the preservation and maintenance of the site, and also has the potential to enhance local economic opportunities and growth for the surrounding area by increased tourism and visitation. I voted in support of the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) this evening.   Whatever the crisis or mission, our service members stand ready to protect and defend our national interests around the globe. They take on a broad range of missions, often risking their own safety, to tackle anything from fighting terror and extremism, to carrying out humanitarian aid missions like we recently saw in regions affected by devastating hurricanes.   Our brave men and women in uniform are trained to carry out their duties, and it is up to us to ensure they have the resources, equipment, and technology they need to stay ahead of the next threat. The National Defense Authorization Act considered today encourages innovation, growth, and sends a clear message that our national security is a top priority. God bless our troops, both at home and abroad, who are working hard to keep us safe.

With so many people living in struggling communities, our approach to tax reform should focus on creating more opportunities for American families. The goal should be to reform our tax system in a way that helps folks bring more dollars home to their families and add more jobs to the American economy.    I was a small business owner, and I understand that the complexity of the tax code does very little to encourage growth. Today, in Senate Finance Committee, I questioned witnesses on U.S. small businesses ability to grow jobs under our current tax system.

Our great nation is home to more than 320 million people spread across almost four million square miles. We have states with nearly 40 million people, and states with less than 600,000 people. To try and dictate health care policy from Washington, D.C. simply does not make sense. Thatâ€™s why I support the Graham-Cassidy solution to empower states to make choices for their people based on their specific health care needs and trends. South Carolina faces different challenges than Oregon, so why would we try and force a one-size-fits-all system on them both?  The fact remains that Obamacare is failing the American people. Skyrocketing premiums, high deductibles and overall uncertainty in the marketplace means we need a new solution. By block granting money directly to states, we take a significant step forward in putting our health care system back in the hands of patients and their doctors while still protecting people with pre-existing conditions, repealing the individual mandate and stopping some burdensome Obamacare taxes. Iâ€™m on board â€“ now letâ€™s go get the votes!

I introduced the bipartisan Lead-Safe Housing for Kids Act of 2017 with my colleagues, Senators Durbin, Menendez, Young Donnelly, and Duckworth. This bill would protect children in federally-assisted housing from lead exposure. We owe it to children both in South Carolina and across the country to ensure that proper inspections are taking place in regards to lead paint, which was not banned for use in housing until 1978.  My mission is to ensure every child from every zip code in the country has the opportunity to succeed, and this bipartisan bill is an important piece of helping ensure low-income families have access to safe housing that can provide a stable environment for their childrenâ€™s dreams to grow.  https://www.scott.senate.gov/press-release/scott-durbin-menendez-young-donnelly-duckworth-introduce-bipartisan-legislation

We must demand accountability from #Equifax. Questioning their former CEO in Banking Committee NOW: https://www.banking.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/hearings?ID=B61BB78D-CF34-4D54-B7F2-F7F982D77D6F

Three Equifax executives sold $1.8 million of the companyâ€™s stock three days after it was breached, and made an extra $655,000 than they would have after the breach was made public. I find it hard to believe that this was pure "luck", while the American people were left holding the bag.    Hereâ€™s the timeline: - On July 29, suspicious activity was reported within Equifax - On August 1, three Equifax executives sold off stock totaling $1.8 million - On September 7, six weeks later, Equifax told the public about the breach - Equifax stock plummets from an August 1 price of $142.46 to $92.98 a shareby September 14 - This drop means the Equifax executives made an extra $655,000 by selling within days of the breach - In total, Equifax lost $6.4 billion of value after the breach was made public - Today, former Equifax CEO Richard Smith testified that executives had no knowledge of the breach when they sold their stock   Watch me question former Equifax CEO Richard Smith in Banking Committee this morning here:

I joined a bipartisan group of senators to reintroduce the Sentencing Reform and Corrections Act of 2017, which would recalibrate prison sentences for nonviolent drug offenders, target violent and career criminals and save taxpayer dollars.  We can both keep violent offenders off the streets and ensure that non-violent offenders are serving time that better matches their offense. I look forward to working with this bipartisan group of Senators to help reduce recidivism, keep violent offenders off the street, and ensure our criminal justice system is both fair and tough. My statement regarding President Trumpâ€™s healthcare executive order signed earlier today:  During a time when South Carolinians, and Americans across the country, stand on the verge of facing more steep premium increases, this is a welcomed action from the administration.  Todayâ€™s announcement is a clear example of how we can help folks gain access to health insurance by increasing affordable options and empowering small businesses to help their employees gain access to coverage. The facts donâ€™t lie. By 2018, nearly fifty percent of all U.S. counties are expected to have only one option on the exchange, leaving more than a quarter of a million people with no option for coverage. Not to mention premiums continue to rise with South Carolinians facing a 31% increase by next year. Todayâ€™s decision shows what we can do to help the American people as we continue the healthcare debate surrounding the repeal and replace of Obamacare.
